pull.title: Add init scripts and docs for Upstart and OpenRC
pull.body: Expanding on @aitorpazos earlier commit of a systemd service file, here are some additional scripts and documentation updates to support Upstart and OpenRC.  Tested on Gentoo/OpenRC 0.12.4 and Ubuntu trusty/Upstart 1.12.1.

events.body: looks good at a quick glance
Is there some reason not to use the Gentoo OpenRC script? It seems a lot more complete...
Yeah, it's nicer but has a weird datadir path.  I'll update with a slightly modified version of it tomorrow...

Yeah, I'm not a fan of the way they just override HOME to get it to stick the datadir in /var/lib/bitcoin/.bitcoin (yuck) and use start-stop-daemon's --make-pidfile and --background to daemonize outside of bitcoind.  I have something that cribs the good stuff they have in there and I'm testing it.  I'll add a commit with the new stuff soon

Ok, I merged in the good stuff from the Gentoo distribution and cleaned things up in general a bit.  I think this is ultimately nicer than the existing Gentoo scripts.  The only thing I can think of is perhaps aiming the documentation a bit more towards doing the install yourself, but it seems that would be best coupled with some work with the gitian build stuff to actually generate binary builds.  What do you guys think?

Oh, also, tested on Gentoo (~amd64 updated yesterday) and Ubuntu 14.04.
Please use /etc/bitcoin/bitcoin.conf and /var/lib/bitcoin/.bitcoin datadir to retain compatibility with existing OpenRC initscript. Additionally, rpcuser should not be required (only rpcpassword).
Nit: I think the default for the system-wide bitcoind should be to run without wallet. This makes it usable for multiple users/applications that want to have their own access to the block chain.
@laanwj How does running the wallet break that use case? Seems harmless to me.

For one, running a wallet makes the security requirements a lot tighter. Without wallet you can have the bitcoin data directory (apart from bitcoin.conf, if that's in your data directory at all) world-readable.
Can you add (maybe in another pull) the necessary files to contrib/debian to install the right things on Ubuntu/Debian?
Anyone still strongly against merging this? Improvements can be made later.
I have another round of changes to commit, but I'm traveling right now.  Can you hold off until the middle of next week?

events.message: Add init scripts and docs for Upstart and OpenRC

events.body: Alright, I've cleaned up the docs a bit and have added explicit warnings about how to set the rpcpassword correctly to the scripts.  Also, the wallet is now disabled by default.  I think these should now  serve as a pretty decent starting point.
@ajweiss Have you tested that existing installs won't be broken with the new OpenRC/systemd stuff?

Automatic sanity-testing: PASSED, see http://jenkins.bluematt.me/pull-tester/p4611_234bfbf6a5fcba37e510e9cb6c1f2a629cd0290e/ for binaries and test log.
This test script verifies pulls every time they are updated. It, however, dies sometimes and fails to test properly.  If you are waiting on a test, please check timestamps to verify that the test.log is moving at http://jenkins.bluematt.me/pull-tester/current/
Contact BlueMatt on freenode if something looks broken.

If I replace the default scripts with the new ones on my Gentoo box with bitcoind-0.9.2.1 from portage, everything looks good.  There might be some potential confusion that could arise from the wallet being disabled by default, but I'm not sure what to do about that.  Maybe a note in the docs?  AFAIK, the systemd scripts are brand new so I don't think it's a problem there.

issue.title: Bitcoind as system background service
issue.body:
When using bitcoind as a wallet-less full node, it would be useful to be able to run it as a system service, so that it starts automatically at startup and can be controlled though the OS's normal service start and stop functionality.

For the Debian/Ubuntu side of things see hippich and fungus' posts here: https://bitcointalk.org/?topic=965.0 . It'd make most sense to integrate this into the PPA. There are two different systems in use here: old-style sysv init scripts, and upstart.

For Windows/OSX I'm not sure what is necessary. At least we'd need new installer packages, separate from the normal "Bitcoin Core Wallet" which provide a node and nothing more.

The installer would also need to create user credentials to run under.

Edit: for the service install, this would also imply moving the configuration to a system-wide instead of user location, for example `/etc/bitcoin.conf` as well as default the data directory to a system-scope location (probably `/var/lib/bitcoin`).

issue.title: Update Debian (Ubuntu) package with bitcoind init scripts
issue.body:
Given Issue #4124 (bitcoind as system service) and now that PR #4611 (init scripts and docs for Upstart and OpenRC) is merged, it would be nice to see some updates to the Debian packaging (in `contrib/debian`, right?) to properly install `bitcoind` as a system service.

It would also be nice to see better documentation on the Debian/Ubuntu package:
- Where it lives (source and binary)
- Better build instructions
- etc

(I've done a little bit of work in this area on my own, but am an Debian/Ubuntu newb. I'm definitely willing to help with testing and documentation.)

References:
- [Debian contrib directory](https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/tree/master/contrib/debian)
- [Bitcoin LaunchPad page](https://launchpad.net/~bitcoin/+archive/ubuntu/bitcoin)

issue.title: Installation scripts for daemon mode on Ubuntu using Upstart
issue.body:
This work is based upon upstream work in bitcoin core on the master branch and in some PRs.
The "Cherry Pick" commit is here: https://github.com/msgilligan/mastercore/commit/55a97b93223919171195fb11c11281c9cdb0be3e

All files (both the "cherry pick" files and the ones that I've added are in the `contrib` subdirectory.

issue.title: Installation scripts for daemon mode on Ubuntu using Upstart (resubmission)
issue.body:
Contains configuration files and an installation script for setting up Master Core (`bitcoind`) in daemon mode on Ubuntu using the Upstart init daemon. This is part of the work necessary to implement Issue #131, but does not address the actual packaging.

Some of the files are from the current [upstream](https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin) `master` branch. The files in `contrib/msc-ubuntu` were created specifically for Master Core (a README and a default `bitcoin.conf` file for Master Core)

Here are some of the merged upstream PR's included in this "back-port" to Master Core.
- [bitcoin #4611](https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/4611)
- [bitcoin #4577](https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/4577)

Upstream issues:
- [bitcoin #4124](https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/issues/4124)

Note: This is a resubmitted PR, the original PR was #129. This PR is now based off of the `mscore-0.0.8` branch and includes a [change](https://github.com/msgilligan/mastercore/commit/440f19274d63b5dfe2599ac5f88b40bc42209aa7) suggested by @dexX7.

comments.body: Sure.  Also, I noticed overnight that the Gentoo ebuild for bitcoind has a nicer OpenRC init file that checks a few more things.  I'll merge in the good stuff from there too...

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,48 @@
+#!upstart
+description "Bitcoin Core Daemon"
+
+start on runlevel [2345]
+stop on starting rc RUNLEVEL=[016]
+
+env BITCOIND_BIN="/usr/bin/bitcoind"
+env BITCOIND_USER="bitcoind"
+env BITCOIND_GROUP="bitcoind"
+env BITCOIND_PIDDIR="/var/run/bitcoind"
+# upstart can't handle variables constructed with other variables
+env BITCOIND_PIDFILE="/var/run/bitcoind/bitcoind.pid"
+env BITCOIND_CONFIGFILE="/etc/bitcoind.conf"
+env BITCOIND_DATADIR="/var/lib/bitcoind"
+
+expect fork
+
+respawn
+respawn limit 5 120
+kill timeout 60
+
+pre-start script
+    # this will catch non-existent config files
+    if ! grep -qs rpcuser "$BITCOIND_CONFIGFILE" ||
+        ! grep -qs rpcpassword "$BITCOIND_CONFIGFILE" ; then
+            echo "ERROR: You must set rpcuser and rpcpassword in" \
comments.body: This should probably either generate a random password and install it, or be changed to clarify that a password should be very randomized and doesn't need to be remembered, as the daemon itself does.

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,63 @@
+#!/sbin/runscript
+
+BITCOIND_CONFIGFILE=${BITCOIND_CONFIGFILE:-/etc/bitcoind.conf}
+BITCOIND_PIDDIR=${BITCOIND_PIDDIR:-/var/run/bitcoind}
+BITCOIND_PIDFILE=${BITCOIND_PIDFILE:-${BITCOIND_PIDDIR}/bitcoind.pid}
+BITCOIND_DATADIR=${BITCOIND_DATADIR:-/var/lib/bitcoind}
+BITCOIND_USER=${BITCOIND_USER:-bitcoind}
+BITCOIND_GROUP=${BITCOIND_GROUP:-bitcoind}
+BITCOIND_BIN=${BITCOIND_BIN:-/usr/bin/bitcoind}
+
+name="Bitcoin Core Daemon"
+description="Bitcoin crypto-currency p2p network daemon"
+
+command="/usr/bin/bitcoind"
+command_args="-pid=\"${BITCOIND_PIDFILE}\" \
+		-conf=\"${BITCOIND_CONFIGFILE}\" \
+		-datadir=\"${BITCOIND_DATADIR}\" \
+		-daemon \
+		${BITCOIND_OPTS}"
+
+required_files="${BITCOIND_CONFIGFILE}"
+start_stop_daemon_args="-u ${BITCOIND_USER} \
+			-N ${BITCOIND_NICE:-0} -w 2000 -R 60"
+pidfile="${BITCOIND_PIDFILE}"
+
+depend() {
+	need localmount net
+}
+
+# verify
+# 1) that the datadir exists and is writable (or create it)
+# 2) that a directory for the pid exists and is writable
+# 3) ownership and permissions on the config file
+start_pre() {
+	checkpath \
+	-d \
+	--mode 0750 \
+	--owner "${BITCOIND_USER}:${BITCOIND_GROUP}" \
+	"${BITCOIND_DATADIR}"
+
+	checkpath \
+	-d \
+	--mode 0755 \
+	--owner "${BITCOIND_USER}:${BITCOIND_GROUP}" \
+	"${BITCOIND_PIDDIR}"
+
+	checkpath -f \
+	-o ${BITCOIND_USER}:${BITCOIND_GROUP} \
+	-m 0660 \
+	${BITCOIND_CONFIGFILE}
+
+	checkconfig || return 1
+}
+
+checkconfig()
+{
+	if ! grep -qs '^rpcpassword=' "${BITCOIND_CONFIGFILE}" || \
+		! grep -qs '^rpcuser=' "${BITCOIND_CONFIGFILE}" ; then
+		eerror "You must set rpcuser and rpcpassword in" \
comments.body: This should probably either generate a random password and install it, or be changed to clarify that a password should be very randomized and doesn't need to be remembered, as the daemon itself does.

comments.body: Well, obviously you can always look up the password again in the file, but bitcoin-cli won't look in /etc[/bitcoin]/bitcoin.conf automatically (yet?).

comments.body: I mean, it's saying "set the rpcuser and rpcpassword". It should be clarified that it's not an rpcuser and rpcpassword that you should be thinking of and remembering. And yeah, it's probably a good idea to fix that somehow -- maybe with a wrapper script or something?

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,78 @@
+Running bitcoind as a system service on Linux 
+=============================================
+
+Sample scripts and configuration files for systemd, Upstart and OpenRC
+can be found in the contrib/init folder.
+
+contrib/init/bitcoind.service:     systemd service unit configuration
+contrib/init/bitcoind.conf:        Upstart service configuration file
+contrib/init/bitcoind.openrc:      OpenRC compatible SysV style init script
+contrib/init/bitcoind.openrcconf:  Optional OpenRC style conf.d file for bitcoind 
+
+1. Users and Groups
+---------------------------------
+
+All three startup configurations assume the existence of a "bitcoind" user
+and group.  They must be created prior to using these scripts.
+
+2. Files
+---------------------------------
+
+All three configurations assume several paths that might need to be adjusted
+to your needs.
+
+bitcoind's config file is assumed to be located at /etc/bitcoind.conf (you can
+use contrib/debian/examples/bitcoin.conf as an example). Once installed, users
+must edit the file in order to update at least these two
+values: rpcuser and rpcpassword . Failing to do so will make the daemon fail
+to start. However, the message written to /var/lib/bitcoind/debug.log file is
+very helpful and no default values should be set:
+
+    YYYY-MM-DD HH:MM:DD Error: To use the "-server" option, you must set
+    a rpcpassword in the configuration file:
+    /etc/bitcoind.conf
+    It is recommended you use the following random password:
+    rpcuser=bitcoinrpc
+    rpcpassword=HdYZ5HGtAF7mx8aTw6uCATtD2maMAK4E12Ysp4YNZQcX
comments.body: If this is a quote, it should be changed to something that's obviously not something you should actually be using, to clarify that it's an example (like YYYY-MM-DD HH:MM:DD in line 31)
